content.raw:
I think we are getting closer.......
Here are a couple answers with their score:
This is switch 32, which is below and to the left of the head.  Below means z should be negative, left means y should be positive.  That is the case for my answer and the real values for the neck frame.  The real values for the head frame are inverted, which is probably because the head frame is indeed inverted, but goes against what we heard earlier, which was to report in the frame that is correct for the robot facing the upright console.  I don't know why my Y value answers are offset vs. the real values.  I suspect that there is a glitch in going from ROS to Gazebo, since those Y values are perfect for where the lights are in rviz.  It could also have to do with inverting the image, since the process for that is a bit arbitrary and if it is not rotated around the exact center, then offsets may occur.

```
#!python

Answer 9: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 0.0000 1.0000]
                    euclidean error        [0.000000]
          Position: answer                 [2.8123 0.5305 0.0464]
                    ground truth (neck)    [3.0009 0.4622 -0.2463]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.8351 -0.4622 -0.0489]
                    euclidean error (neck) [0.354727]
                    euclidean error (head) [0.997496]
```


This next one is switch 34, which is lined up below switch 32.  So the y should be the same and the z should be more negative.  Again true for my answer and for the real neck frame.  The real answer in the head frame moves in the positive direction for z.  Note that all three show a magnitude change in z of 0.13, which is correct.

```
#!python

Answer 7: Color:    answer                 [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]
                    ground truth           [0.0000 1.0000 0.0000]
                    euclidean error        [0.000000]
          Position: answer                 [2.8240 0.5325 -0.0830]
                    ground truth (neck)    [2.9800 0.4623 -0.3764]
                    ground truth (head)    [2.8315 -0.4623 0.0829]]
```
I'm fine with reporting in whatever frame you think is best, but I need to know what to submit for the actual entry.

Below means z should be negative, left means y should be positive. That is the case for my answer and the real values for the neck frame. The real values for the head frame are inverted, which is probably because the head frame is indeed inverted, but goes against what we heard earlier, which was to report in the frame that is correct for the robot facing the upright console. I don't know why my Y value answers are offset vs. the real values. I suspect that there is a glitch in going from ROS to Gazebo, since those Y values are perfect for where the lights are in rviz. It could also have to do with inverting the image, since the process for that is a bit arbitrary and if it is not rotated around the exact center, then offsets may occur.

The real answer in the head frame moves in the positive direction for z. Note that all three show a magnitude change in z of 0.13, which is correct.
